ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Questions 1,2, 6, 10:For a seminar class, I was disappointed with the lack of structure during discussion. The readings rarely provided enough fodder for meaningful discussion, and often time were not interrelated enough for the topic at hand. I found myself frustrated with the lack of relation among the articles assigned.At the beginning of class it was mentioned that lecture would be minimal, and that was promising. However, the lecture portion seemed to increase each week. For a seminar class, I feel like the discussion should be much more structured, and we should be trying to either dissect policy or issues, or reconstruct viable alternatives.

I'm not sure this class should be taught again unless there's a prof who currently specializes in Africa. It would have been great to have an area expert teach the class. Same goes for the TA. Since so few people actually took the course, I'm not sure there's enough demand for it.Perhaps issue expert guest speakers could have made the class better.The discussions were a bit too loose. They often went in a number of tangential directions. It would have been better to have a shorter class (2 hours) that had a strong direction.The fact that the prof. announced the length of the paper 10 days before it was due was really not cool. There's no reason that the length couldn't have been made clear either from the beginning (in the syllabus) or when we presented our final paper proposals.
Small class size was conducive to candid discussions and enabled classmates to get to know each other better. The readings were also generally great.
some of the readings

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: - Readings need to inform the topics of discussion. There should be questions that come to mind from reading the articles that provide the material for discussion!- More of a seminar structure- Directing the discussions in a meaningful, useful way- By cutting the class to 2 hours, having less time may force the conversation to be more structured
More structured class time, perhaps broken up into current events, professor introduction/lecture, and then group discussion. 3 hours of just discussion is too long.
The entire course. This was a failed experiment.
see response to #12

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both the TA and professor were very available and were prepared to lead the class (at least after the first few classes when they were deciding on a format).
TA has minimal knowledge about Africa, and instructor only has a background in Kenya, so anything outside of Kenya and energy stuff is conjecture.
seemed like class might not have been a top priority. or maybe because it's new, there are still a lot of issues to be worked out.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I am an African studies student doing work on energy in West Africa. This course was very informative for me and helped me broaden my understanding of actors and challenges in the context of the African environment. This was the only course of its type offered this semester and I hope Rob continues to offer it.
This course was not helpful to me.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to take a course specifically on Africa and there aren't a ton of offerings - this one seemed to fit the bill.
I was excited that FES was finally offering a course on African issues, which is one of my areas of interest, and I wanted to support that endeavor.
interested in learning more about environmental issues in Africa

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
No. It was awful.
a little bit, but it definitely needs improvement if it's going to be offered again.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
No.
some of the readings were helpful

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: ... start your final paper before the last week, if it remains an 8,000-10,000 word assignment.

Do the readings and think about how each reading might fit into the topic you want to write about for the term paper.Don't be afraid to voice your opinion about the class in class (format, readings, etc.)
don't take it unless it's been revised and restructured.
